A B S T R A C T
Clay minerals, as abundant natural resources, are among the most suitable supporting materials for nano metal. In this manuscript, new Fe3O4 nanoparticle/rectorite (Fe3O4/rectorite) catalysts are developed via in-situ precipitation oxidation reaction. Various physicochemical characterizations of Fe3O4/rectorite show that Fe3O4 nanoparticles (nano-Fe3O4) with an average particle diameter of approximately 10–20 nm are effectively loaded on the surface of acid leached rectorite (Al-rectorite) and have low coaggregation and improved dispersion. Moreover, the catalytic activity of Fe3O4/rectorite on degradation of P-chlorophenol by heterogeneous Fenton method is studied. Results of degradation experiments show that Fe3O4/rectorite has higher degradation efficiency of P-chlorophenol than bare nano-Fe3O4. Regeneration studies also show that Fe3O4/rectorite maintains 100% of its maximum P-chlorophenol degradation capacity after seven consecutive cycles. Fe3O4/rectorite can be easily separated by magnetic separation, and thus has good stability and reusability. The degradation mechanism of Fe3O4/rectorite is adsorption coupled with a Fenton-like reaction, which accounts for P-chlorophenol degradation of up to 625 mg/g. This work demonstrates a new composite material for the effective remediation of refractory organic compounds from wastewater.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
P-chlorophenol is a hazardous and toxic substance that poses serious danger to the environment. P-chlorophenol is relevant to wastewater remediation for its solubility and severity to aquatic and terrestrial life (Taherian et al., 2013; Nguyen and Juang, 2015; Kurian and Nair, 2015). In the past few years, various methods of wastewater treatment have been widely used to remove P-chlorophenol (Păcurariu et al., 2013; Duan et al., 2014). Traditional technologies for removing Pchlorophenol include thermal, chemical, and biological treatment processes. However, these traditional technologies have some limitations. For example, biological treatment needs a long reaction time, because the microbial activity of degrading pollutants is destroyed by Pchlorophenol. Thermal treatment may release other harmful
compounds. In addition, chemical method requires a post-treatment to remove pollutants from the contaminated environment (Li et al., 2009; Nguyen and Juang, 2015, Chen et al., 2017a, 2017b; Acata et al., 2018). Therefore, alternative degradation techniques must be sought to address these problems.
Recently, Fenton technology, as an advanced oxidation process, has been widely used to treat a variety of organic pollutants from wastewater, especially non-biodegradable and persistent pollutants (Kurian and Nair, 2015; Huang et al., 2017). The Fenton reaction involves the reaction of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) with a metal catalyst to form a hydroxyl radical (%OH) that non-selectively attacks the organic pollutants for mineralization (Li et al., 2016). Traditional homogeneous Fenton catalysts had many shortcomings, such as the production of iron sludge and narrow pH requirement (Ezzatahmadi et al., 2017). To

overcome these shortcomings, heterogeneous Fenton catalysts were proposed to replace the homogeneous Fenton catalysts (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b). Different kinds of ferric oxide catalysts can be used as heterogeneous catalysts to activate H2O2 to produce more %OH that can decompose organic pollutants into inorganic salts, CO2, and H2O (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b). However, these essential catalysts exhibited relatively low degradation ratio and weak catalytic activity that subsequently resulted in a continuous urgent demand for a new green catalyst (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b; Ezzatahmadi et al., 2017).
Among different kinds of catalysts, iron oxide minerals, particularly nanoparticle magnetite (nano-Fe3O4), are now receiving increasing attention (Wu et al., 2011; Boruah et al., 2017). Nano-Fe3O4 has magnetic properties and can be easily separated from the terminal solution through magnetic separation. Moreover, it has strong catalytic activity, and can be used in heterogeneous Fenton-like catalysts to remove environmental pollutants. However, coaggregation of nano-Fe3O4 in wastewater reduces its reactivity in aqueous solutions, and this has been studied in various methods for overcoming nano-Fe3O4 coaggregation (Wu et al., 2011; Boruah et al., 2017).
Using supporting materials for Nano-Fe3O4 is promising in solving these problems. Clay minerals have been used as environmental remediation agents to remove pollutants from wastewater because of their low cost and good adsorption performance (Ezzatahmadi et al., 2017; Liu et al., 2018; Liu et al., 2019). Moreover, clay minerals can be used as support materials for catalysts because of their large specific surface area, stability, and rough surface potential (Wu et al., 2011; Ezzatahmadi et al., 2017). In previous studies, we synthesized and used such materials as support for the degradation of bisphenol A, 2–4-dichlorophenol, and acid orange II. These included nano zero-valent iron (NZVI)/diatomite composite, NZVI/palygorskie composite, NZVI/bentonite composite, and NZVI/nano nickel/diatomite composite (Ezzatahmadi et al., 2017). A new acidic NZVI/diatomite composite was recently used to degrade bisphenol A (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b). These composite materials have fast degradation rates and high removal efficiency for the treatment of organic pollutant wastewater. However, several drawbacks remained in the synthesis and practical application of composite materials, with difficulty in separation from wastewater, weak reusability and stability, and high cost being the most common (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b; Ezzatahmadi et al., 2017). Supporting materials must have high stability, and environmental friendliness; moreover, they must prevent the coaggregation of nano-Fe3O4 and improve catalytic activity (Xu et al., 2009; Ezzatahmadi et al., 2017; Deng et al., 2017).
Rectorite is an interlayer clay mineral that consists of an inextensible dioctahedral mica-like layers and an expandable dioctahedral smectite like-layer at a ratio of 1:1 (Jiang et al., 2013; Liu et al., 2014; Deng et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2018; Sun et al., 2018a, 2018b). Rectorite structure can easily cleave the smectite-like interlayer; moreover, rectorite can be inserted or shed in many exchange groups to obtain a large specific surface area. Additionally, the cation exchange between layers of smectite can make rectorite as a good adsorbent for removing cation pollutants, such as Hg(II), NH4+, Sr(II), Pb(II), Cr(VI), Pb2+, and organic dyes (viz. methylene blue and neutral red) (Zhang
et al., 2005; Hong et al., 2008; Zhang et al., 2011; Zhao et al., 2014; Wang et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2017). In recent years, researchers have prepared rectorite composite materials for wastewater treatment. For instance, metal oxide catalyst particles with rectorite for the removal of pollutants (Wu et al., 2011) and Fe2O3-pillared with rectorite were employed to study photodegradation of nitrophenol and azo-dye rhodamine B (Zhang et al., 2010). Rectorite has many excellent properties that make it suitable for the synthesis of nano-Fe3O4 composite materials. However, few attempts have been recorded for synthesizing nanoFe3O4 loaded rectorite, which can be separated from the solution easier using a simple magnet than using centrifugation or conventional filtration (Zhang et al., 2009; Liu et al., 2015; Lu et al., 2015; Zhu et al., 2017).
In this study, we synthesized Fe3O4/rectorite and nano-Fe3O4 by one-step co-precipitation pathway and then characterized it by different techniques. The catalytic activity of Fe3O4/rectorite and nano-Fe3O4 on degradation of P-chlorophenol by Fenton-Like reaction as well as the effects of different parameters on the best reaction conditions were studied. Finally, a mechanism of P-chlorophenol degradation by Fe3O4/ rectorite was discussed in this study.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: Rectorite was provided by the Shun He filter media plant in Dang Jiang Kou City, Hubei Province, China. P-chlorophenol (≥99%), H2O2 (30%), ferrous sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO4·7H2O), HCl (36.5%), ethanol (100%), ammonium hydroxide (NH3·H2O), NaOH, H2SO4 (98%), and ferric chloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O) were the analytical grade, purchased from He Fei chemical reagent company (China).

sections.heading: 2.2. Preparation of Fe3O4/rectorite and nano-Fe3O4
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows Fe3O4/rectorite and nano-Fe3O4 prepared by co-precipitation method, which was similar in the previously described methods (Wu et al., 2011; Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b; Ezzatahmadi et al., 2017).
(1) A total of 40 g of rectorite was added to 1 L of 5 M HCl solution for acid leaching, and the solution mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h using a magnetic stirrer hot plate. The solid product was filtered and washed with deionized water (DI) to result in the acid leached product rectorite (Al-rectorite) (Fig. 1A–C).
(2) The 68.5 mg of Al-rectorite sample was added into DI and dispersed in 250 mL of DI. After magnetic stirring treatment for > 2 h, a transparent and homogeneous Al-rectorite dispersion solution was obtained. N2 was used to stir the dispersion solution for 3 h (Fig. 1D).
(3) FeSO4·7H2O (1.350 mmol) and FeCl3·6H2O (2.699 mmol) were dispersed in 25 mL of DI, and Al-rectorite dispersion solution was added. The dispersion solution was stirred vigorously for 30 min with N2 at 80 °C. NH3·H2O (5.0 mL) was added to the reaction
mixture, which was then stirred vigorously for 2 h (Fig. 1E). (4) After the above reaction was completed, the solid–liquid was se-
parated by centrifugation to separate a solid, which was washed with 2.5 L of 100% ethanol. The precipitate was dried in a vacuum oven at 40 °C ± 1 °C for 24 h. The solid sample obtained was Fe3O4/rectorite (Fig. 1F and G). The preparation method of nanoFe3O4 was similar to that above (Wu et al., 2011).

sections.heading: 2.3. Material characterization techniques
sections.text: The identification of rectorite, Al-rectorite, Fe3O4/rectorite, and nano-Fe3O4 was recorded by using X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Dan Dong Hao Yuan 2700, China) operated under Cu target, electric tension of 40 kV, electric current of 30 mA, and scan rate of 4°/min. Al-rectorite, Fe3O4/rectorite, and nano-Fe3O4 of multi-point BET surface area was measured by using Quantachrome Nova 3000e automated surface area analyzer (American Quantachrome Instruments Company, USA). The surface elements of Fe3O4/rectorite were investigated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Thermo Escalab 250 XI). The chemical composition of rectorite was determined by using Shimadzu X-RayFluorescence (XRF)-1800 using Rh radiation. The surface functional groups of rectorite and Fe3O4/rectorite were determined by Nicolet Nexus 50+ Continuum Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectrometer. The morphology of rectorite, Al-rectorite, Fe3O4/rectorite, and nano-Fe3O4 was characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM) (Philips XL30 ESEM). The elemental composition and structural analysis were examined by using transmission electron microscope (TEM) (JEOL 2100F, Japan), and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX). Elemental analysis of solid sample was characterized using VARIO ELIII analyzer (Elemental Analysis System Co., Ltd., Germany). Total organic carbon (TOC) was determined by TOC/TN analyzer (Jena multi N/C 2100). Determination of free radicals in the reaction solution was performed using electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrophotometer (JEOL, JES-FA200). Samples of magnetic susceptibility analysis were conducted by a Bartinton MS2 analyzer. Determination of Fe ion concentration in solution was done using Wayee WYS 2200 atomic absorption spectrometer.

sections.heading: 2.4. P-chlorophenol degradation via heterogeneous Fenton-like experiments
sections.text: The degradation experiments were conducted in such a way that 50 mL of reaction solution was first added into a cone bottle with a stopper. The dosages of catalyst and H2O2 were 0.005–0.04 g and 0.05–1 mL, respectively. The concentration of P-chlorophenol was 60–110 mg/L. The initial pH of the reaction solution was adjusted to a working solution pH of 3 ± 0.5 with NaOH and H2SO4. The dispersion was stirred for a predetermined time using a magnetic stirrer. After the reaction was completed, it was centrifuged for 5000 rpm for 30 min, and the glass centrifuge tube was used to separate the solid. Subsequently, a glass pipette was used to remove approximately 1 mL supernatant that was injected into a 2 mL amber glass vial containing 10 μL 2 M Na2SO3 solution to quench any·OH (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b). After heterogeneous Fenton-like reaction, the catalyst was repeatedly washed and dried for further reuse in the reusability and stability experiments. The concentration of P-chlorophenol was quantitatively analyzed by Chromaster Ultra Rs HPLC equipped with Luna 5 C18 column and UV absorption detector. In this experiment, methanol–water (70:30) for a mobile phase was used with a flow rate of 1 mL/ min, and the injection volume was 40 L in 280 nm wavelength analysis.

sections.heading: 3.1. XRD and XRF patterns of the samples
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of rectorite, Al-rectorite, nano-Fe3O4, and Fe3O4/rectorite. The reflections at 2θ = 3.35°, 7.01°, and 19.79°
(JCPDS (01–0572)) of rectorite and at 2θ = 26.61°, 35.35°, and 62.58° (JCPDS (02–0471)) of quartz are shown in Fig. 2(I)A. Rectorite is mainly composed of rectorite and quartz. As shown in Fig. 2B, the reflection of rectorite after acid leaching remains constant, but its intensity decreases (especially at 2θ = 3.35° and 7.01°). Acid leaching does not destroy the structure of rectorite. When the intensity of reflection of rectorite decreases, Al3+ in rectorite octahedral sheets is removed during the acid leaching process, and H+ is filled in the interlayer region of rectorite instead of extracting cations. The intensity of the reflections of rectorite was decreased by converting Al-(SieO)3 into three Si-OH (Zhu et al., 2018; Chen et al., 2019; Bao et al., 2019). Fig. 2(II) shows the low-intensity of the reflections of the XRD patterns of Al-rectorite and Fe3O4/rectorite. The reflections at 2θ = 3.35°, 7.01°, and 19.79° (JCPDS (01–0572)) (Fig. 2(II)A) of Al-rectorite shifted to 2θ = 4.31°, 8.13°, and 22.36° after loading nano-Fe3O4 (Fig. 2(II)B), respectively. The relative intensities of reflection were changed in the composite material (Fe3O4/rectorite) compared with those in Al-rectorite because of the delaminated phenomena and dehydration of smectite-like layers. A similar finding has been reported elsewhere (Xu et al., 2009; Wu et al., 2011). Fig. 2(I)B and C show five characteristic reflections of nano-Fe3O4 (2θ = 30.10°, 35.68°, 43.08°, 57.18°, and 62.74°) (JCPDS (02–1035)). These reflection points correspond to the characteristic reflections of Fe3O4 (Li et al., 2016). Therefore, magnetic Fe3O4 nanoparticles were successfully installed on the Al-rectorite surface. This approach is conducive to the dispersion of Fe3O4 nanoparticles, improvement of the Fe3O4 nanoparticle activity, promotion of the synergistic effect of Fe3O4 nanoparticles and Al-rectorite, and further enhancement of the degradation ratio of P-chlorophenol. This finding will be discussed in Sections 3.7–3.16.
XRF measurements of the rectorite chemical compositions are shown in Table S1 (Bao et al., 2019). The rectorite mainly contained SiO2 and Al2O3. In addition, trace concentrations of P2O5, Cr2O3, and ZnO were identified from the matrix rectorite contamination, and this finding was consistent with a previous study (Atanasova et al., 2016; Bao et al., 2019).

sections.heading: 3.2. SEM and TEM patterns of the samples
sections.text:
The surface morphologies of rectorite, Al-rectorite, nano-Fe3O4, and Fe3O4/rectorite were characterized by SEM in Fig. 3. Fig. 3A indicates the lamellar structure of rectorite, and fine grains and rod-like crystals that look like fine flakes can be observed as strip-like fibrous needle crystals. As illustrated in Fig. 3B and C, rectorite retains its original form after acid leaching. In addition, the layered structure and rough porous surface of Al-rectorite are also revealed in Fig. 3B and C. The XRD analysis indicated that the irregular scaly morphology on the surface of layered and fibrous structures is mainly caused by acid leaching of aluminium ions, which are suitable supporting materials for nano-Fe3O4. On the other hand, Fig. 3D–F indicates that the synthesized nano-Fe3O4 was mostly spherical and dramatically coaggregated to form a chain-like iron material. In principle, Nano-Fe3O4 coaggregation decreases the effective surface-active sites of nanoparticles (Xu et al., 2009; Li et al., 2016; Weng et al., 2018). Nano-materials generally coaggregate because the large surface energy facilitates ease of coaggregation (Li et al., 2016; Sun et al., 2018a, 2018b). In addition, nanoFe3O4 has magnetic attraction tendency between the nano-particles, thereby supporting easier coaggregation (Xu et al., 2009; Li et al., 2016; Sun et al., 2018a, 2018b). As shown in Fig. 3G and H, supported nanoFe3O4 exists on the Al-rectorite surface and enters the Al-rectorite pores, assuring good dispersion and poor coaggregation. High-resolution SEM of Figs. 3I and J confirm that Al-rectorite was covered by the nano-Fe3O4, in which the surface of Fe3O4/rectorite became coarser than that of Al-rectorite (Figs. 3B and C); moreover, the nano-Fe3O4 was immobilized on Al-rectorite supports to end up with the formation of nano-Fe3O4 composite material, which can effectively improve the catalytic activity and prevent coaggregation.
Fig. 4 shows TEM images of rectorite, Al-rectorite, nano-Fe3O4, and Fe3O4/rectorite at different magnification levels. Fig. 4A reveals that TEM images of rectorite exhibited a wrinkled film on the planar surface. As presented Fig. 4B, fragments were observed after rectorite acid leaching, which was beneficial for nano-Fe3O4 loading. This finding is consistent with that obtained by SEM. On the other hand, Figs. 4C, D and F shows a sesame cake-like structure of nano-Fe3O4. This is mainly attributable to the strong tendency of nano-Fe3O4 for coaggregation, which was mainly caused by magnetic attraction between nano-Fe3O4. A similar result was reported from another study (Chen et al., 2017a,b). The EDS spectra of nano-Fe3O4 in Fig. 4E confirm that nano-Fe3O4 mainly consisted of Fe and O and a small amount of Mg, Al, Si, and Ca. The chemical calculation of nano-Fe3O4 and the mass percentage of Fe to O elements were 2.6, and the nano-Fe3O4 mass percentage of Fe to O elements slightly decreased to 2.28, which was within the measurement errors of the system. This implies that nano-Fe3O4 was successfully fabricated. Fig. 4D shows the iron chain-like structure of nano-Fe3O4. The average size of this nano-Fe3O4 was approximately 10–20 nm (Fig. 4F), showing detection of certain extent of coaggregation. The main reason was that nano-Fe3O4 was a magnetic material, and magnetic attraction between the nanoparticles supports easier coaggregation. This finding is consistent with that obtained by SEM.
Moreover, the TEM image of Fe3O4/rectorite (shown in Fig. 4G) reveals a significant amount of spherical nano-Fe3O4 of approximately 10–20 nm was wrapped, which was invisible on the surface of Al-rectorite, indicating that nano-Fe3O4 was successfully introduced to the Alrectorite. A significant amount of nano-Fe3O4 was mainly attached to the surface of Al-rectorite compared with those that were not loaded (Fig. 4G of pink circle). The loading of nano-Fe3O4 on the Al-rectorite substantially resisted the aggregation. The TEM shown on Fig. 4H, I, K and L also asserts that the nano-Fe3O4 particles were effectively loaded and well distributed on Al-rectorite sheets. Some subunits of size 10–20 nm were integrated with nano-Fe3O4 cluster, implying that the precipitation process formed some large particles from aggregation of small particles. The EDS spectra of nano-Fe3O4 in Fig. 4J confirm that Fe3O4/rectorite mainly consisted of Fe, Al, Si, and O and small amounts
of Ca and K. Compared with EDS spectra of nano-Fe3O4 (Fig. 4E), the Fe element in Fe3O4/rectorite decreased, whereas the Si, Al, and O elements increased. Most of the O originated from the Al-rectorite and nano-Fe3O4. In addition, Al and Si originated from the Al-rectorite. This finding also shows that nano-Fe3O4 was successfully introduced to the Al-rectorite.
A TEM image with EDS maps for Fe3O4/rectorite in Fig. 5 shows that the Fe-enriched region was characterized by a wide range of red spherical particles, indicating the formation of discrete Fe phases. As previously demonstrated in TEM images, the phase was composed of nano-Fe3O4 (Fig. 4D). In the O-EDS map, the O-concentration region was characterized with green spherical particles, indicating a discrete O phase. The regions of Si, Al, Mg, Ca, and K low density were evenly distributed on the surface of Fe3O4/rectorite. Fe3O4/rectorite of Si, Al, Mg, Ca, and K element came from Al-rectorite. Most of the O originated
from the Al-rectorite and nano-Fe3O4. In addition, Fe and Si originated from the Al-rectorite and nano-Fe3O4. This finding also shows that nano-Fe3O4 was successfully introduced to the Al-rectorite. TEM and EDS maps of the Fe3O4/rectorite analysis indicate that a large amount of nano-Fe3O4 formed on the inner part or surface of the Al-rectorite. Nano-Fe3O4 could be homogeneously dispersed on the surface of Alrectorite.

sections.heading: 3.3. FTIR spectroscopy of samples
sections.text:
As presented in Fig. S1, the FTIR spectrum analysis of rectorite and Fe3O4/rectorite (Fig. S1A) shows that the peaks at 3637 cm−1 from the hydroxyl stretching vibration of Al–O–H and 3441 and 1633 cm−1 of absorbance bands were attributed to H–O–H stretching vibration of structural water and other water molecules in rectorite (Chen et al.,
2019; Bao et al., 2019). The peak at 1014 cm−1 (Fig. S1A—pink heartshaped logo) was related to in-plane of Si–O–Si stretching vibration. This peak is shifted to a higher wavenumber at 1098 cm−1, which is assigned to the out of plane Si–O–Si stretching vibration of Fe3O4/ rectorite (Fig. S1B—pink color heart-shaped logo). As illustrated by the rectorite (Fig. S1A), the peaks at 827 cm−1 were related to Si–O–Al bending. After acid leaching and nano-Fe3O4 loading (Fig. S1B), a peak at 827 cm−1 disappeared, and a new one was formed at 801 cm−1 (Fig. S1B—violet color heart-shaped logo), which is related to Si–OH. As shown in Fig. S1A, the peaks at 707 cm−1 were related to AleO out of plane, and the peak value at 452 cm−1 is related to SieO bending vibration (Xu et al., 2009; Zhang et al., 2010; Wu et al., 2011; Zhao et al., 2014). The peak at 623 cm−1 (Fig. S1B—olive color circular-shaped logo) was related to FeeO bond of nano-Fe3O4 that was observed in Fe3O4/rectorite (Xu et al., 2009; Li et al., 2016), thereby showing that nano-Fe3O4 was effectively loaded on the Al-rectorite surface. The FTIR
image analysis shows that the absorption peaks were shifted to the lower frequency in the Fe3O4/rectorite spectra (refer to subpanel labels C, D, E, F, G, H, and I of Fig. S1B). This finding confirmed the existence of intermolecular interactions between Al-rectorite and nano-Fe3O4, because the latter had the ion exchange capacity to form the adsorbed Fe2+ and Fe3+ on the Al-rectorite surface, thereby ultimately causing some interactions between nano-Fe3O4 and Al-rectorite surface (Xu et al., 2009). The Si–O–Al bands transformed into Si–OH ones after acid leaching and nano-Fe3O4 loading, thereby changing the surface properties of the rectorite without destroying its structure.

sections.heading: 3.4. XPS results
sections.text:
In this study, we used XPS to analyze the element composition of the Fe3O4/rectorite surface. As shown in Fig. 6A, the binding energies (BE) of Ca2p, Fe2p, O1s, Si2p, and Al2p were 350.01, 714.35, 533.63,
105.03, and 76.1 eV, respectively. Fig. 6B shows the XPS analysis of O1s Fe3O4/rectorite in which four peaks with BEs of 530.10, 530.88, 531.66, and 532.33 eV were observed. The peak at 530.1 eV was induced by lattice oxygen in Fe3O4 (Briggs and Beamson, 1993; Reitz et al., 2013; Wilson and Langell, 2014). In addition, the peaks at 530.88 and 531.66 eV were related to the monodentate oxygen atoms (HeO) and monodentate and bidentate oxygen species (Si–O–Si) (Briggs and Beamson, 1993; Reitz et al., 2013; Wilson and Langell, 2014); The Fe3O4/rectorite surface was mainly bidentate by the intensity ratios of monodentate to bidentate oxygen atoms. The residual peak at 532.33 eV can be attributed to the chemical equivalent oxygen in the bidentate bond (O–C=O) (Briggs and Beamson, 1993; Zhu et al., 2011; Reitz et al., 2013; Wilson and Langell, 2014). The reactive oxygen species of chemisorbed oxygen of Fe3O4/rectorite play a vital role in oxidation reaction. As illustrated in Fig. 6C, the XPS analysis of Fe2p Fe3O4/rectorite shows four peaks with BEs. The Fe2p3/2 peak of BE at 710.83 eV represented the Fe3+ octahedral species (Briggs and Beamson, 1993; Reitz et al., 2013; Wilson and Langell, 2014). The BE at 724.78 eV of Fe2p1/2 indicates the existence of Fe3O4 or octahedrally coordinated Fe2+ (Zhu et al., 2011). The relatively low BE peak at 712.61 eV was related to Fe3+, and the corresponding Fe3+ satellite was attributed to 718.68 eV. The overall XPS peak analysis of the samples confirmed that Fe3+ and Fe2+ were present in nanocomposites (Fe3O4/rectorite).

sections.heading: 3.5. BET of samples
sections.text:
Fig. S2 shows the nitrogen (N2) adsorption–desorption isotherms (Fig. S2A) as well as the pore size distribution charts of Fe3O4/rectorite, nano-Fe3O4, and Al-rectorite. The BET specific surface areas of Al-
rectorite, Fe3O4/rectorite, and nano-Fe3O4 were estimated to be 30.90, 59.84, and 65.73 m2/g, respectively. The entire nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm analysis of Fe3O4/rectorite and NanoFe3O4 showed typical type-IV isotherms with distinct H3 type hysteresis loops. The Al-rectorite showed typical type-II isotherms with distinct H4 type hysteresis loops at the relative pressure P/P0 0.35–0.9, which confirms the formation of uniform mesoporous structures (Han et al., 2017; Bao et al., 2019). Compared with Al-rectorite, the hysteresis loop area of the Fe3O4/rectorite was larger (Refer to C and D of Fig. S2B), showing that the incorporation of nano-Fe3O4 into the pores and fissures or onto the surface of Al-rectorite formation piled pore increased their porosity. The corresponding pore size distribution curves of Barrett–Joyner–Halenda also confirmed the existence of mesoporous structure (Yang et al., 2015).
Fig. S2B and Table S2 show the specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of Fe3O4/rectorite, nano-Fe3O4, and Al-rectorite. Compared with Al-rectorite, the Fe3O4/rectorite showed increment of specific surface area of 30.90–59.84 m2/g, pore volume of 0.07–0.20 cm3/g, and increased average pore size of 2.77–2.90 nm. This is mainly attributable to fissure and piled pore load by nano-Fe3O4 into the pores and fissures onto the surface Al-rectorite formation, whereas the slight increase in average pore size is attributed to the clogging of the micropores and existence of trace stable mesopores (Han et al., 2017). The loading of nano-Fe3O4 into the pores and fissures onto the Al-rectorite confirmed that Al-rectorite carried and dispersed the Nano-Fe3O4 toward increasing surface area and active sites for Fenton reaction.

sections.heading: 3.6. Magnetism of Fe3O4/rectorite
sections.text:
The hysteresis loops of Fe3O4/rectorite were studied, and their magnetization characteristics were observed. Fig. 7(A) shows that the saturation magnetization (ms) of Fe3O4/rectorite is 30.28 emu/g. Meanwhile, Fig. 7(B) shows that the hysteresis loops of Fe3O4/rectorite exhibit almost zero coercivity and remanence, thereby indicating that the type of Fe3O4/rectorite is superparamagnetic. Fig. 7(C) shows the superparamagnetism phenomenon, and Fe3O4/rectorite was verified to be easily separated by an external magnetic field. This phenomenon indicated that the Fe3O4/rectorite catalyst presented a particularly important advantage because it can be used for recycling (see Section 3.14 for a detailed discusion).
The above analysis shows that nano-Fe3O4 has been successfully loaded on the surfaces of Al rectorite. Thus, agglomeration of nanoFe3O4 can be prevented, and its catalytic activity can be improved. In previous studies, no maghemite (r-Fe2O3) has been detected when coprecipitation was used to synthesize nano-Fe3O4. A similar finding has been reported elsewhere (Wu et al., 2011; Yang et al., 2015). However, nano-Fe3O4 and r-Fe2O3 feature extremely similar lattice structures as rFe2O3 is mainly formed by secondary transformation of nano-Fe3O4 under oxidation conditions, in which Fe2+ in nano-Fe3O4 is completely replaced by Fe3+ (3Fe2+ → 2Fe3+). Hence, the octahedral position occupied by 1/3Fe2+ produces vacancies (Zhao, 2017; Mirbagheri and Sabbaghi, 2018; Zhou et al., 2019).

sections.heading: 3.7. Comparison of degradation effects of different catalysts on Pchlorophenol
sections.text: Fig. 8 shows that only 6% degradation ratio of P-chlorophenol was achieved via the degradation of H2O2 alone (Fig. 8A). This is mainly attributed to the weak oxidation capacity of H2O2 because degrading Pchlorophenol by using H2O2 alone is difficult. However, 32% and 48% removal of P-chlorophenol were achieved via the adsorption of rectorite alone and nano-Fe3O4 alone, respectively (Fig. 8B and C). Furthermore, 54% removal of P-chlorophenol was achieved by the Fe3O4/rectorite alone, which exhibited more abundant functional groups compared with that of nano-Fe3O4 (Fig. 8D), and 56% degradation ratio was achieved by rectorite with H2O2 (Fig. 8E). The degradation ratio of Fe3O4/rectorite was 100% higher than that of bare nano-Fe3O4 (98%) in the presence of H2O2 (Fig. 8G and F). This is because the synergistic effect between Al-rectorite and nano-Fe3O4 resulted in a higher degradation ratio than the other catalysts mentioned above. See Section 3.16 for a more detailed discussion.

sections.heading: 3.8. Effect of catalyst dosage
sections.text: The performance of nano-Fe3O4 and Fe3O4/rectorite on the degradation of P-chlorophenol under catalyst dosage of 0.005–0.04 g is indicated in Fig. S3. P-chlorophenol degradation ratio increased with increasing dosage of nano-Fe3O4 from 0.005 to 0.01 g and Fe3O4/rectorite from 0.005 to 0.008 g owing to increasing the number of active sites for the production of P-chlorophenol and %OH for the degradation of P-chlorophenol in the reaction system (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b). Nevertheless, further increasing nano-Fe3O4 to > 0.01 g and Fe3O4/ rectorite to > 0.008 g did not influence the degradation performance and P-chlorophenol removal, which persisted at 100% because the degradation ratio of Fe3O4/rectorite was higher than that of bare nanoFe3O4. This result was attributable to the best dispersal and low coaggregation tendency of Fe3O4/rectorite shown in Figs. 3 and 4. The nanoFe3O4 that was immobilized onto rectorite support improved the catalytic activity and prevented coaggregation. The active sites on Fe3O4/ rectorite surface enhanced the decomposition and iron dissolution, thereby forming more %OH (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b). Synergistic effects were notably present between the nano-Fe3O4 and Al-rectorite, ultimately improving the catalytic activity (See Section 3.16 for more detailed discusion). The optimal catalytic dosage of the experiment was found to be 0.008 g for Fe3O4/rectorite and 0.01 g for nano-Fe3O4.

sections.heading: 3.9. Effect of initial P-chlorophenol concentration
sections.text:
The performance of nano-Fe3O4 and Fe3O4/rectorite on the degradation of P-chlorophenol under initial P-chlorophenol concentration of 60–110 mg/L was investigated (Fig. S4). The results showed that the P-chlorophenol degradation ratio of 100% was achieved for Fe3O4/ rectorite and nano-Fe3O4 as the initial P-chlorophenol concentration increased from 60 to 90 mg/L. However, the degradation ratio decreased as initial concentration of P-chlorophenol increased from 100 to 110 mg/L. The two major reasons for the negative effect of the initial concentration of P-chlorophenol on P-chlorophenol degradation are as follows:
(1) As initial P-chlorophenol concentration increased from 60 to 110 mg/L, the P-chlorophenol molecules were adsorbed on the surface of nano-Fe3O4, and Fe3O4/rectorite occupied the active sites, thereby resulting in decreased %OH formation on the catalyst surface (Yang et al., 2015).
(2) For low-concentration P-chlorophenol solutions, the molar ratio of oxidant to P-chlorophenol was high because the initial concentration of oxidant was the same for different initial concentrations of P-chlorophenol solutions. The high oxidant/P– chlorophenol ratio was favorable for the degradation of P-chlorophenol.
The entire analysis shows that 100 mg/L was selected as the optimal initial P-chlorophenol concentration for Fe3O4/rectorite and nano-
Fe3O4.

sections.heading: 3.10. Effect of H2O2 dosages
sections.text:
To study the effect of H2O2 dosage on the degradation performance, an experiment was conducted with H2O2 dosage varying in the range of 0.05–1 mL (Fig. S5A). The analysis showed that degradation ratio increased as H2O2 dosage increased from 0.05 mL to 0.5 mL. This was attributable to the classical Haber–Weiss mechanism (Li et al., 2016), in which %OH generated from Fe2+ through H2O2 reacted with Fe3+ to regenerate Fe2+ circularly, producing more %OH radicals in the Fenton reaction. Sufficient %OH cannot be produced at low H2O2 dosages (< 0.5 mL) for complete degradation of the P-chlorophenol. However, further increasing the H2O2 dosage from 0.5 to 1 mL did not influence the increase in degradation ratio (Fig. S5A), thereby confirming that 0.5 mL dosage of H2O2 was required for the complete 100% degradation of P-chlorophenol for nano-Fe3O4 and Fe3O4/rectorite. The degradation ratio of Fe3O4/rectorite was higher than that of nano-Fe3O4 at H2O2 dosages of 0.05–0.5 mL. The Fe3O4/rectorite provided additional reactive sites to efficiently accelerate the electron transformation from Fe2+ to Fe3+ because the additional active sites on the surface of Fe3O4/rectorite can catalyze H2O2 to produce more %OH to degrade Pchlorophenol in the Fe3O4/rectorite with H2O2 system (Li et al., 2016). Therefore, 0.5 mL can be the optimum H2O2 dosage for the degradation of the specified amount of initial P-chlorophenol amount.
The TOC removal ratio increased as H2O2 dosage increased from 0.05 to 1 mL. Moreover, increasing H2O2 dosages (0.05 to 1 mL) resulted in increased removal of TOC for Fe3O4/rectorite compared with nano-Fe3O4 (Fig. S5B). Fe3O4/rectorite effectively removed more TOC than nano-Fe3O4, and was mainly linked to the iron-leaching phenomenon (Fig. S5C). As H2O2 dosages increased, iron leaching was observed via the concentration of iron in the solution, as shown in Fig. S5C. High degradation ratio of P-chlorophenol was observed for Fe3O4/ rectorite because additional %OH can be produced with iron leaching (Eqs. (1) and (2)). The optimal H2O2 dosage of 0.5 mL for Fe3O4/rectorite and nano-Fe3O4 was selected and used in the subsequent experiments.

sections.heading: 3.11. Effect of initial pH
sections.text: The effect of initial pH value on the degradation ratio of P-chlorophenol was investigated in the pH range of 2–9 (Fig. S6). The result indicated that the degradation ratio of P-chlorophenol for nano-Fe3O4 and Fe3O4/rectorite was 99.11% and 99.13% at the initial pH of 2.0, and increasing the initial pH value to 3.0 increased the degradation of nano-Fe3O4 and Fe3O4/rectorite for P-chlorophenol to the maximum (100%). Fig. S6 shows that the highest degradation ratio at pH of 3 was attributable to the following major reasons: higher oxidation capability of %OH (2.8 eV) in lower pH, availability of more dissolved fractions of iron species in the lower pH, slower decomposition rate and relative stability of H2O2 in acidic solution, and enhanced reaction rate from the formation of metal oxide-pollutant inner-sphere complexes that will promote reaction (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b). However, significant decrease in degradation ratio was observed when the initial pH increases from 4 to 9 because high pH rapidly decomposed H2O2 to O2 and H2O (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b). The P-chlorophenol degradation ratio was reduced from 100% to 69.92% and from 100% to 75.14% for Fe3O4/ rectorite and nano-Fe3O4, respectively. The optimal initial pH of 3 was selected for Fe3O4/rectorite and nano-Fe3O4 and used in the subsequent experiments.

sections.heading: 3.12. Effect of reaction time on the degradation of P-chlorophenol
sections.text: Fig. S7 shows the relationship between the degradation time and degradation ratio of nano-Fe3O4 and Fe3O4/rectorite. P-chlorophenol degradation ratio of 89.7% was observed during the first 15 min and reached 98.5% in 30 min for Fe3O4/rectorite. Subsequently, increment of the P-chlorophenol degradation ratio of up to 98.5% to 100% was observed between 30 and 60 min, which remained constant until 24 h. A similar pattern was observed for nano-Fe3O4 and required 15 min to reach 87.1%, which was slower than that of Fe3O4/rectorite. A Pchlorophenol degradation ratio of 100% was achieved in 175 min for nano-Fe3O4, which was also slower than that of Fe3O4/rectorite. This fast degradation rate of Fe3O4/rectorite was mainly because with a lower pH (pH = 3), it can release Fe2+, and the H2O2 can oxidize this Fe2+ and produce %OH in the solution. Moreover, the fast degradation rate at 60 min for Fe3O4/rectorite implied that H2O2 exhibited a high tendency to quickly oxidize Fe2+ to produce %OH, finally causing a fast decrease in Fe2+ (Fig. S7C).

sections.heading: 3.13. Reusability and stability of Fe3O4/rectorite
sections.text:
Fig. 9 shows that the reusability of the Fe3O4/rectorite was evaluated under the optimum condition set previously in Section 3.12, which was identical with the first oxidation cycle. After each recycling, the Fe3O4/rectorite was treated by magnetic separation, followed by drying and reuse. Fig. 9A shows that Fe3O4/rectorite has relatively good long-term reusability and activity because the degradation ratio of P-chlorophenol was 100% for all cycles (1–7). Fig. 7C clearly shows that applying an external magnetic field can easily separate the Fe3O4/rectorite. This phenomenon shows a superior recyclability performance of Fe3O4/rectorite because the magnetic susceptibility of rectorite and Fe3O4/rectorite was estimated to be 27.13 × 10−8 and 7589.72 × 10−8 m3/kg, respectively (See the Section 3.6).
Recycling by magnetic activity is an effective and economical way for easy and continuous utilization of Fe3O4/rectorite. The Fe3O4/rectorite would be regenerated after being reclaimed by magnetic separation technology. Therefore, this Fe3O4/rectorite with relatively higher magnetic susceptibility can be easily reclaimed for further use.

sections.heading: 3.14. EPR experiments of samples
sections.text:
The EPR experiments were carried out with 5, 5′-dimethyl-1-pyrrolidine N-oxide (DMPO) to detect any free radicals produced (Fig. 10). Previous studies have found that %OH and %O2– exist in the process of degrading organic pollutants by Fenton-like reaction with magnetic catalysts, and %OH plays a significant role in the Fenton-like reaction. % O2– in aqueous solution is generally unstable, and our experimental results did not monitor %O2– by EPR experiments (Rush and Koppenol, 1986; Han et al., 2017; Bao et al., 2019). In Fig. 10, the use of DMPO as a spin-trapping agent to detect the characteristic 1:2:2:1 quartet signal indicated the presence of %OH in Fenton-like reaction. The peak of
Fe3O4/rectorite was higher than that in rectorite; moreover, the XRF results showed the rectorite has some Fe2O3 and CuO (Table S1), which asserts a synergistic effect between the nano-Fe3O4 and Al-rectorite because the Fe chemical compositions of Fe3O4/rectorite increased during loading nano-Fe3O4. This process produced more %OH (Eqs. (1) and (2)), which finally improved the catalytic activity of Fe3O4/rectorite. See Section 3.16 for the detailed discussion.

sections.heading: 3.15. Elemental analysis of carbon
sections.text:
Elemental analysis experiments were performed to determine the carbon content (P-chlorophenol/intermediates product) of the samples before and after the adsorption/Fenton-like reaction, as well as to determine the mechanism of the Fe3O4/rectorite with H2O2 degradation in the P-chlorophenol reaction process. The corresponding result was considered as one of the indirect parameters showing the P-chlorophenol adsorption and degradation capacity of the composite material. The mass percentage of carbon determined by elemental analysis is shown in Fig. 11. Before the start of the experiment, trace amounts of mass percentages of carbon that were detected on the surface of rectorite resulted from the surface contamination of adventitious carbon (Ma et al., 2016a, 2016b; Bao et al., 2019). At this stage, the mass percentage of carbon was 0.25%. The Fe3O4/rectorite mass percentage of carbon was 0.1%, which slightly decreased in acid leaching (HCl). After adsorption of P-chlorophenol, its carbon content increased noticeably and reached 13.44% and 10.38% for Fe3O4/rectorite and nanoFe3O4, respectively. This result confirmed that additional P-chlorophenol was adsorbed on Fe3O4/rectorite and nano-Fe3O4. After
Fenton-like reaction of P-chlorophenol, the carbon content in Fe3O4/ rectorite and nano-Fe3O4 decreased noticeably to 0.53% and 0.36%, respectively. This carbon content decline was attributed to the effective degradation of the P-chlorophenol by the %OH and %O2– functional groups formed during the Fenton-like reaction. See Section 3.16 for more discusion.

sections.heading: 3.16. Mechanism discussion
sections.text:
The degradation mechanism of P-chlorophenol on the Fe3O4/rectorite included two major processes (Fig. 12). Stage 1: Refer to the analyses in Sections 3.7 and 3.15. Fe3O4/rectorite can adsorb part of P-chlorophenol from the aqueous solution, become saturated, and form solid–liquid phases. The remaining part of the P-chlorophenol remains in the aqueous solution, and the Fe3O4/ rectorite starts releasing iron ions simultaneously from the liquid–liquid phases (Fig. 12). Stage 2: Refer to the analyses in Sections 3.7, 3.14, and 3.15. The Fe2+ and Fe3+ produced by partial dissolution of Fe3O4/rectorite under pH of 3 conditions may initiate the decomposition of H2O2 via homogeneous Fenton-like chain reaction (liquid–liquid phase). The inverse spinel crystal structure and electrons can be transferred between Fe3+ and Fe2+ in the octahedron, allowing the Fe species to be reversibly reduced and oxidized while maintaining the same structure (Li et al., 2016; Han et al., 2017). First, in the aqueous solution, the H2O2 can react with dissolved Fe2+ to form %OH, Fe3+, (Eq. (1)) %O2−/%HO2, and Fe2+ (Eq. (2)). The resulting %OH (Eq. (1)) can react with H2O2 to form HO2%/%O2– (Eq. (3)). Fe2+ was converted to Fe3+ by oxidation of %OH (Eq. (4)). Therefore, all these reactions cause iron ions to circulate in the solution system (Eqs. (1)–(7)). The %OH produced on the surface of Fe3O4/rectorite plays a significant role in the degradation of P-chlorophenol. Therefore, we speculate that a similar chain reaction occurs on the surface of Fe3O4/rectorite but different from that in the aqueous solution. In addition, %OH generated on the surface of Fe3O4/rectorite through chain reaction participates in the degradation of P-chlorophenol (solid–liquid phase). This may explain the decrease in degradation of P-chlorophenol in Fe3O4/rectorite performance during reuse, and is similar to the results by Luo and Hang et al. (Patel and Willson, 1973; Rush and Koppenol, 1986; Luo et al., 2010; Han et al., 2017; Wen, 2018).

sections.heading: 3.17. Catalyst performance comparison
sections.text: Table 1 shows the maximum removal of P-chlorophenol by using some catalysts and adsorbents. Fe3O4/rectorite was superior to other catalysts and adsorbents. Thus, immobilizing nano-Fe3O4 onto Al-rectorite may offer many advantages, and the coaggregation of nano-Fe3O4 can be effectively prevented. Most importantly, a synergistic effect that existed between the nano-Fe3O4 and Al-rectorite can improve the catalytic activity of Fe3O4/rectorite.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
(1) A new Fenton catalyst of Fe3O4/rectorite composite material was prepared via in- situ growth of spherical nano-Fe3O4 on the surface of Al-rectorite via precipitation oxidation process. Nano-Fe3O4 that was successfully embedded in the Al-rectorite matrix had an
average size of 10–20 nm, thereby reducing the coaggregation in the Al-rectorite matrix and improving dispersion. Fe3O4/rectorite had a higher specific surface area than Al-rectorite. The Fe3O4/ rectorite optimum reaction conditions were found to be a catalyst dosage of 0.008 g, H2O2 dosage of 0.5 mL, pH of 3–4, P-chlorophenol concentration of 100 mg/L, and reaction time of 60 min. The Fe3O4/rectorite of 625 mg/g exhibited good catalytic capacity for P-chlorophenol degradation, as well as good removal effect on P-chlorophenol.
(2) The Fe3O4/rectorite mechanism of degradation of P-chlorophenol was mainly ascribed to adsorption coupled with a Fenton-like reaction. Most importantly, Fe3O4/rectorite had good regeneration capability and can be separated easily by utilizing external magnets. Therefore, Fe3O4/rectorite can be used safely to remediate organic pollutants in aqueous solutions.
(3) Related future work (which has already been initiated in our laboratory) includes the synthesis, characterization (including Mossbauer spectroscopy and TEM diffraction), and investigation of the catalytic performance of nano-Fe3O4, r-Fe2O3, Fe3O4/rectorite, and r-Fe2O3/rectorite for the degradation of various organic pollutants.

metadata.abstractText: Clay minerals, as abundant natural resources, are among the most suitable supporting materials for nano metal. In this manuscript, new Fe3O4 nanoparticle/rectorite (Fe3O4/rectorite) catalysts are developed via in-situ precipitation oxidation reaction. Various physicochemical characterizations of Fe3O4/rectorite show that Fe3O4 nanoparticles (nano-Fe3O4) with an average particle diameter of approximately 10–20 nm are effectively loaded on the surface of acid leached rectorite (Al-rectorite) and have low coaggregation and improved dispersion. Moreover, the catalytic activity of Fe3O4/rectorite on degradation of P-chlorophenol by heterogeneous Fenton method is studied. Results of degradation experiments show that Fe3O4/rectorite has higher degradation efficiency of P-chlorophenol than bare nano-Fe3O4. Regeneration studies also show that Fe3O4/rectorite maintains 100% of its maximum P-chlorophenol degradation capacity after seven consecutive cycles. Fe3O4/rectorite can be easily separated by magnetic separation, and thus has good stability and reusability. The degradation mechanism of Fe3O4/rectorite is adsorption coupled with a Fenton-like reaction, which accounts for P-chlorophenol degradation of up to 625 mg/g. This work demonstrates a new composite material for the effective remediation of refractory organic compounds from wastewater.
